'''Enter Shikari''' (stylised as '''enter: shikari''' and occasionally as '''ΣΠΤΣ℞ SΗΦΚ∆℞Φ''') are a British rock band formed in [[St Albans]], [[Hertfordshire, England|Hertfordshire]], England in 1999 by bassist Chris Batten, lead vocalist and keyboardist Rou Reynolds, and drummer Rob Rolfe. In 2003, guitarist Rory Clewlow joined the band to complete its current line-up, and it adopted its current name. In 2006, they performed to a growing fanbase at [[Download Festival]] as well as a sold-out concert at the [[London Astoria]]. Their debut studio album, ''[[Take to the Skies]]'', was released in 2007 and reached number 4 in the [[UK Albums Chart|Official UK Album Chart]], and has since been certified gold in the UK. Their second, ''[[Common Dreads]]'', was released in 2009 and debuted on the UK Albums Chart at number 16;<ref>{{Cite web |title=Radio 1 – The Official Chart with Reggie Yates – The Official UK Top 40 Albums Chart |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/radio1/chart/albums.shtml |access-date=12 March 2011 |publisher=BBC}}</ref> while their third, ''[[A Flash Flood of Colour]]'', was released in 2012 and debuted on the chart at number 4. Both have since been certified silver in the UK. The band spent a considerable amount of time supporting the latter release through the [[A Flash Flood of Colour World Tour]], before beginning work on a fourth studio album, ''[[The Mindsweep]]'', which was released in 2015. Their fifth studio album ''[[The Spark (album)|The Spark]]'' was released in 2017. Their sixth album ''[[Nothing Is True & Everything Is Possible]]'' was released in April 2020.

Enter Shikari have their own record label, Ambush Reality. However, they have also signed distribution deals with several major labels to help with worldwide distribution. Their eclectic musical style combines influences from rock music genres with those from various [[electronic music]] genres.

==History==

=== Beginnings (1999–2006) ===

In 1999 a band named Hybryd formed, consisting of Rou Reynolds on guitar and vocals, Chris Batten on bass guitar, and Rob Rolfe on drums. They released an EP called ''[[Commit No Nuisance]]'', which featured the tracks "Perfect Pygmalion", "Look Inside", "Torch Song", "Honesty Box" and "Fake". In 2003, with the addition of guitarist Rory Clewlow, Hybryd became Enter Shikari. The band was named after ''Shikari'', a boat belonging to Reynold's uncle. In a 2011 interview, Rolfe explained that: "Shikari is a [[Hindi]] word for hunter."<ref>{{Cite web |title=Enter Shikari | Artist Interviews |url=http://www.accessallareas.net.au/artists/Enter_Shikari.php |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304025238/http://www.accessallareas.net.au/artists/Enter_Shikari.php |archive-date=4 March 2011 |access-date=12 March 2011 |publisher=Access All Areas}}</ref> After the band's line-up and name change, Reynolds focused his musical efforts on vocals and electronics instead of guitar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Enter Shikari: Unplugged & Personal |url=https://headlinermagazine.net/headliners/enter-shikari-unplugged-and-personal.html |access-date=13 March 2017 |website=Headliner Magazine}}</ref>

During 2003 and 2004, the band released three demo EPs (''[[Nodding Acquaintance]]'', ''Anything Can Happen in the Next Half Hour'' and ''[[Sorry You're Not a Winner EP|Sorry You're Not a Winner]]'') that were available from their gigs and their website, featuring original versions of some songs that were eventually re-recorded for their debut album, ''[[Take to the Skies]]''. They would frequently make appearances at their local youth club, The Pioneer Club, where they would play alongside other local bands.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pioneerclub.co.uk/?page_id=3762|title = History}}</ref><ref>Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211205/pmsloh93nyA Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20211117144921/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pmsloh93nyA Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite web| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pmsloh93nyA| title = The Pioneer Club at 70 | via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> They had another demo EP planned for release in 2005 (no such EP materialised, although recordings surfaced online). For this the first versions of "Return To Energiser" and "Labyrinth" were recorded. Early versions of "OK Time for Plan B" and "We Can Breathe in Space" were also recorded around this time but it's unclear if these were destined for the EP. It was at this time that Kerrang! Radio's Alex Baker picked up on the band, and as he didn't have a physical release to play, he streamed "OK Time For Plan B" off the band's Myspace page, straight onto the airwaves.

In August 2006 they released a video of the single "[[Mothership (song)|Mothership]]" which became the single of the week on the [[iTunes Store]]. Their first physical single featured re-recorded versions of "[[Sorry You're Not a Winner/OK Time for Plan B]]", which had previously been featured on one of the demo EPs. It was released on 30 October 2006. It was limited to 1000 copies of each format and sold out within the first week of release. In mid January 2007, Enter Shikari's first single, "[[Mothership (song)|Mothership]]", entered the UK singles chart for one week at number 151, on Downloads only (despite its physical formats not being eligible for charts [at the band's request]). This was followed a week later by "[[Sorry You're Not a Winner/OK Time for Plan B]]", which charted at number 182 on the singles chart (despite its physical formats being ineligible for charts [at the band's request]) and number 146 in the Download Chart. In addition "[[Sorry You're Not a Winner/OK Time for Plan B]]" featured on the [[EA Sports]] video game titles [[NHL 08]] and [[Madden 08]]. Enter Shikari secured a spot on the Gibson/Myspace stage at 2006's [[Download Festival#Download 2006|Download Festival]].

They also had interviews with popular music press such as ''[[Kerrang!]]'' and ''[[Rock Sound]]''. On 4 November 2006, they became only the second unsigned band to ever sell out [[London Astoria]] (the first being [[The Darkness (band)|The Darkness]]).

They also made the ''[[NME]]'''s "New Noise 2007", a list of the bands it considers most likely to achieve success in the coming year (previous years lists have included the likes of [[Arcade Fire]], [[Hot Chip]] and [[Bloc Party]]).

The next single released was "[[Anything Can Happen in the Next Half Hour]]", on 5 March 2007. This was the band's second single to be released from their forthcoming debut album. It contained a re-recorded version of the song "Anything Can Happen in the Next Half Hour". It reached 27 in the Official UK chart.

The band released a compilation album titled ''[[The Zone (Enter Shikari)|The Zone]]'' just after the debut album, this contained various demo tracks and previously released singles.

=== ''Take to the Skies'' (2007–08) ===
{{main|Take to the Skies}}

The band's debut album, ''[[Take to the Skies]]'', was released on 19 March 2007 and on 25 March it reached number 4 in the UK Official Album Charts. It contained re-recordings of many of the songs that had featured on the demo EPs and singles that were released prior to the release of the album.

During the month of March 2007 it was announced they would be playing at [[Download Festival]], [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]], [[Give it a Name]], [[Glastonbury Festival]], [[Oxegen]] festival in Ireland and [[Rock am Ring]] in Germany. On 30 March 2007, Enter Shikari announced that their next single would be "[[Jonny Sniper]]"<ref>[http://www.smashmus15ic.co.uk/news.php?newsid=321 Enter Shikari Announce New Single! – Smash Music<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111113730/http://www.smashmus15ic.co.uk/news.php?newsid=321 |date=11 January 2016 }}</ref> and would be released on 18 June. The song's video was premiered on 21 May. The single received bad reviews from ''NME''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Enter Shikari – Enter Shikari – Track Reviews |url=https://www.nme.com/reviews/enter-shikari/8672 |access-date=12 March 2011 |website=NME|date=13 June 2007 }}</ref>

Enter Shikari had performed over 500 times by 2007 and played on the [[Gibson Guitar Corporation|Gibson]]/[[MySpace]] stage at 2006's [[Download Festival]]. On 14 May 2007, Enter Shikari started their first North America tour. This was followed by three more North American tours.

On 13 May 2008, the band released the first in a series of videos called "Enter Shikari: In the 'Low". The videos, posted on the band's YouTube page, showcased the band as they recorded their new single, "[[We Can Breathe In Space, They Just Don't Want Us To Escape]]", and demoed new material. One of the new songs set to feature on the album was 'Step Up', which was first performed at [[Milton Keynes]] Pitz on 28 June 2008, the warm up show to [[Projekt Revolution]] the following day.

===''Common Dreads'' (2009–2010)===
{{main|Common Dreads}}
[[File:Enter Shikari Live @ Heaven.jpg|thumb|left|Enter Shikari live at [[Heaven (nightclub)|Heaven]] in London in 2009. From left to right: Clewlow, Rolfe, Reynolds and Batten.]]

It was confirmed by ''[[NME]]'' that Enter Shikari had finished working on their second album, ''[[Common Dreads]]'', in March 2009 and announced that they would tour the UK and Europe during 2009. They also made available a free download of a new song, "Antwerpen", from their website.<ref>{{Cite web |date=9 March 2009 |title=Enter Shikari finish new album, confirm tour dates |website=[[NME]] |url=https://www.nme.com/news/enter-shikari/43312}}</ref> On 15 April 2009 "Juggernauts" was played on Radio 1 as Zane Lowe's "Hottest Track in the World" and was released as a single on 1 June 2009 with "All Eyes on the Saint" as its B side. The band also had help from musician Danny Sneddon who helped with the recording of "Juggernauts".<ref>[http://www.entershikari.com/store/products,juggernauts-single-preorder_5.htm] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727180315/http://www.entershikari.com/store/products,juggernauts-single-preorder_5.htm|date=27 July 2013}}</ref> On 1 May Kerrang featured their track-by-track of the album. ''Metal Hammer'' were the first to review the album online with a track-by-track.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Enter Shikari Review: 'Common Dreads' Track-By-Track |url=http://www.metalhammer.co.uk/uncategorized/enter-shikari-review-common-dreads-track-by-track |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502200946/http://www.metalhammer.co.uk/uncategorized/enter-shikari-review-common-dreads-track-by-track/ |archive-date=2 May 2009}}</ref>

''[[Common Dreads]]'' was released through Ambush Reality on 15 June 2009 and debuted at No. 16 on the UK top 40 album chart. The second single to be released from Common Dreads was "[[No Sleep Tonight (Enter Shikari)|No Sleep Tonight]]".<ref>{{Cite web |date=24 June 2009 |title=Enter Shikari announce dates |url=http://www.idiomag.com/peek/89879/enter_shikari |access-date=28 August 2009 |publisher=[[idiomag]]}}</ref> The 7-inch vinyl, CD single and [[MP3]] download was released on 17 August 2009. A slightly modified version of the song "Wall" was released as a radio single, and a video for the song "Zzzonked", made of clips of a live show played at [[University of East Anglia|Norwich UEA]], was also released.

A 2-disc version of ''Common Dreads'' was released in January 2010.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Exclusive: Enter Shikari Announce Remix Records  |url=https://www.rocksound.tv/news/read/exclusive-enter-shikari-announce-remix-records |access-date=27 March 2020 |website=Rocksound.tv}}</ref> Frontman Rou Reynolds announced that "we’ve got a different artist for each single from Hospital Records to do drum 'n' bass remixes so we'll be releasing that as a 12". Then we're doing the same thing with (dubstep label) True Tiger who've done a dubstep remix of each single." However it was later said in a Radio 1 interview that in fact they were only having their main singles remixed.

The single "Thumper"<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lowe |first=Zane |date=19 January 2010 |title=Zane Lowe's Hottest Records blog: Hottest Record – Enter Shikari – Thumper |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/zanelowe/2010/01/hottest_record_enter_shikari_t.html |access-date=12 March 2011 |publisher=BBC}}</ref> was released on 19 January 2010, on BBC Radio One, as well as the new single "Tribalism", which was first played on Radio 1 on 16 February 2010. These songs come off the new B-sides and remixes album ''[[Tribalism (album)|Tribalism]]'', which was released on 22 February 2010.

Throughout February–March 2010, Enter Shikari joined the Australian summer festival Soundwave along with other bands such as [[A Day to Remember]] and [[Architects (British band)|Architects]], playing shows in Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth. The band then continued to tour Japan with [[A Day to Remember]] and [[Escape the Fate]] and in April–May 2010, they served as a support act, along with [[August Burns Red]] and [[Silverstein (band)|Silverstein]] on [[A Day to Remember]]'s ''Toursick''.

On 18 and 19 December, Enter Shikari hosted two Christmas Party shows at [[University of Hertfordshire|The Forum]] in Hatfield, Hertfordshire. Special guest supports included [[Rolo Tomassi]], [[Young Guns (band)|Young Guns]], [[Dark Stares]], [[Don Broco]] and [[The Qemists]].<ref name="Enter Shikari Announce Christmas Party">{{Cite web |date=18 December 2010 |title=Enter Shikari Christmas Party 2010 |url=http://www.last.fm/event/1682915+Enter+Shikari+Christmas+Party+2010 |publisher=[[Last.fm]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=15 January 2011 |title=An Enter Shikari Christmas Part One – Hatfield, Herts – Dec 2010 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZjRjvqmoHjw  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/ZjRjvqmoHjw |archive-date=21 December 2021 |url-status=live|via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> The audio from the shows was released via the band's limited edition box-set ''[[Live from Planet Earth - Bootleg Series Volume 3]]''.

=== ''A Flash Flood of Colour'' (2011–12) ===
{{main|A Flash Flood of Colour}}
On 14 June 2010, Enter Shikari announced that they had returned to the studio to do a "one off new track" called "[[Destabilise]]" which was released as a download on 26 October 2010, and a limited edition coloured 7-inch vinyl on 29 November 2010.

In June 2011, the band signed to [[Hopeless Records]] in the US, and embarked on the [[Warped Tour 2011|Vans Warped Tour]] for the second year in a row.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Jentzen |first=Aaron |date=27 June 2011 |title=Vans Warped tour sizzles in San Antonio |work=[[San Antonio Express-News]] |url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/default/article/Vans-Warped-tour-sizzles-in-San-Antonio-1441269.php |access-date=29 June 2011}}</ref>

In mid-2011, the band released another one-off single called "[[Quelle Surprise]]" before releasing the first single, "[[Sssnakepit]]" and "[[Gandhi Mate, Gandhi]]" in September and December, respectively, off their third album.

The band released ''A Flash Flood of Colour'' on 16 January 2012, and played three album release shows in London, Kingston upon Thames, and Leeds.

At the end of the first week of the album being released, the album reached number four in the U.K charts.

Later that year, the band began their first tour of ''[[A Flash Flood of Colour]]'' in February by heading out to Tokyo, Japan for one show, before playing [[Soundwave (Australian music festival)|Soundwave Festival]], including a couple of 'sideshows' on their off-days.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Australian Shows |url=http://www.entershikari.com/two-australian-headline-shows/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029023302/http://www.entershikari.com/two-australian-headline-shows/ |archive-date=29 October 2012 |access-date=5 September 2012 |publisher=Enter Shikari}}</ref> The band continued their tour across the world, travelling to the United States,<ref>{{Cite web |title=USA/Canada April/May shows |url=http://www.entershikari.com/usacanada-aprilmay-shows// |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406050817/http://www.entershikari.com/usacanada-aprilmay-shows/ |archive-date=6 April 2012 |access-date=8 April 2012 |publisher=Enter Shikari}}</ref> South Africa,<ref>{{Cite web |title=OppiKoppi |url=http://www.oppikoppi.co.za |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190327014806/https://oppikoppi.co.za/ |archive-date=27 March 2019 |access-date=28 July 2019}}</ref> Europe, [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]], [[Pukkelpop]], [[FM4 Frequency Festival]], [[Sonisphere]] in Spain, [[T in the Park]], [[Rock am Ring and Rock im Park]], and many more, ranging from the end of May to the start of September.

In Summer 2012's [[Kerrang!]] Awards, the band scooped 'Best Live Band' for the second time, along with Rou Reynolds winning 'Hero of the Year.' They were also nominated for best album, but lost out to [[Mastodon (band)|Mastodon]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |title=Kerrang Awards 2012 Winners |url=http://www.kerrang.com/blog/2012/06/the_kerrang_awards_fuelled_by_1.html |magazine=Kerrang! |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610013044/http://www.kerrang.com/blog/2012/06/the_kerrang_awards_fuelled_by_1.html |archive-date=10 June 2012 |access-date=5 September 2012 |url-status=dead}}</ref>

In November 2012 the band announced the launch of their own beer "Sssnakepit", a 5% lager brewed in conjunction with Signature Brew, which was launched in Manchester and sold on the 'A Flash Flood of Christmas' tour at venues across the UK.<ref>{{Cite news |date=30 November 2012 |title=Enter Shikari Reveal Their Very Own Sssnakepit Beetr |work=RockSound |url=http://www.rocksound.tv/news/article/enter-shikari-reveal-their-very-own-sssnakepit-beer |access-date=30 November 2012 |quote=...Enter Shikari reveal their very own sssnakepit beer..}}</ref>

The band were also nominated for Best British Band and Best Live Band at the [[Kerrang! Awards 2013]], but lost out to [[Bring Me the Horizon]] and [[Black Veil Brides]] respectively.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kerrang! |url=http://www.kerrang.com/blog/2013/06/relentless_kerrang_awards_2013_1.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130930214517/http://www.kerrang.com/blog/2013/06/relentless_kerrang_awards_2013_1.html |archive-date=30 September 2013 |access-date=23 April 2014}}</ref>

===''Rat Race'' EP (2013)===
In April 2013, the band released a non-album single named "[[The Paddington Frisk]]", later announcing that it was part of a then unnamed three track EP due for release later that year (''[[Rat Race (Enter Shikari song)|Rat Race EP]]''). On 5 June 2013, the band announced via their official Twitter that they were recording a video for the new single "[[Radiate (Enter Shikari Song)|Radiate]]", which was first played by [[Zane Lowe]] on his [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]] show on 10 June. The song was his Single of the Week.<ref name="entershikari.com">{{Cite web |title=Enter Shikari ▿ RADIATE – 10.06.13 |url=http://www.entershikari.com/radiate-10-06-13/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022051538/http://www.entershikari.com/radiate-10-06-13/ |archive-date=22 October 2014 |website=entershikari.com}}</ref> 5 months later, "Rat Race" was released, the three tracks were then amalgamated into the ''Rat Race EP'', along with a [[trance music|trance]] remix of "Radiate" created by Reynold's side project – Shikari Sound System.

The band headed out on an extensive tour of the UK and Ireland throughout April and May, purposefully playing in towns that don't usually get shows, as a thank you to those fans who usually have to travel to larger cities all the time to see bands. Support for the tour was Hacktivist. This tour was the first time the songs "[[The Paddington Frisk]]" was played, as well as "[[Juggernauts (song)|Juggernauts]]" b-side "All Eyes on the Saint" from 2009

===''The Mindsweep'' (2014–2016)===
{{main|The Mindsweep}}

In late 2012, bassist Chris Batten said that the band will begin working on their fourth studio album after their current touring has finished sometime in 2013. However, Batten also affirmed that the album would not be ready for release in that year.<ref>{{Cite web |date=18 December 2012 |title=NME News Enter Shikari to begin work on new album in 2013 |url=https://www.nme.com/news/enter-shikari/67781 |website=NME}}</ref>

On 8 October 2014, the band announced that their fourth album would be titled ''[[The Mindsweep]]'', and would be released on 19 January 2015.<ref>{{Cite web |title=NEWS: Enter Shikari confirm fourth album, 'The Mindsweep', out January 19th 2015! |url=http://www.deadpress.co.uk/42401/news-enter-shikari-confirm-fourth-album-the-mindsweep-out-january-19th-2015 |website=DEAD PRESS! – Alternative music news, reviews, interviews and more!|date=8 October 2014 }}</ref> The album was anticipated by singles "[[The Last Garrison]]"<ref>{{Cite web |date=20 October 2014 |title=Enter Shikari – "The Last Garrison" World Exclusive |url=http://www.entershikari.com/the-last-garrison-world-exclusive/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103033853/http://www.entershikari.com/the-last-garrison-world-exclusive/ |archive-date=3 November 2014 |access-date=2 November 2014 |publisher=Enter Shikari}}</ref> and "[[Anaesthetist (song)|Anaesthetist]]".<ref>{{Cite web |date=5 January 2015 |title=Anaesthesist |url=http://www.entershikari.com/anaesthetist/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150106020749/http://www.entershikari.com/anaesthetist/ |archive-date=6 January 2015 |access-date=5 January 2015 |publisher=Enter Shikari}}</ref> In addition, two tracks were also released between November and December 2014: "[[Never Let Go of the Microscope]]" and "Slipshod".<ref>{{Cite web |date=26 November 2014 |title=Never Let Go of the Microscope |url=http://www.entershikari.com/never-let-go-of-the-microscope/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225021959/http://www.entershikari.com/never-let-go-of-the-microscope/ |archive-date=25 December 2014 |access-date=29 November 2014 |publisher=Entershikari.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=15 December 2014 |title=Slipshod (Official Video) |url=http://www.entershikari.com/slipshod-official-video/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225021108/http://www.entershikari.com/slipshod-official-video/ |archive-date=25 December 2014 |access-date=15 December 2014 |publisher=Entershikari.com}}</ref> On 12 January 2015 they put for the streaming on their website the entire new album.<ref>{{Cite web |date=12 January 2015 |title=The Mindsweep Pre-Release Stream |url=http://www.entershikari.com/the-mindsweep-pre-release-stream/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115022814/http://www.entershikari.com/the-mindsweep-pre-release-stream/ |archive-date=15 January 2015 |access-date=13 January 2015 |publisher=Enter Shikari}}</ref> In May 2015 they covered [[System of a Down]]'s ''[[Chop Suey! (song)|Chop Suey!]]'' for ''[[Rock Sound]]'''s compilation ''Worship and Tributes'',<ref name="rocksound.tv">{{Cite web |title=Here's EVERYTHING You Need To Know About The CD That Comes FREE With RS200 |url=http://www.rocksound.tv/news/read/heres-everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-cd-that-comes-free-with-rs200 |website=Rock Sound Magazine}}</ref> while in June they participated at ''Ultimate Rock Heroes'' compilation by ''[[Kerrang!]]'' with a cover of "[[Know Your Enemy (Rage Against the Machine song)|Know Your Enemy]]", originally by [[Rage Against the Machine]].<ref name="rocksound.tv" /> On 30 October they released their first remix album, ''[[The Mindsweep: Hospitalised]]'', featuring remixes from drum and bass label [[Hospital Records]] artists.

On 12 January 2016, a single called "[[Redshift (Enter Shikari song)|Redshift]]" premiered on Annie Mac's show on [[BBC Radio 1]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=18 August 2015 |title=Enter Shikari + Hospital Records Presents... |url=http://www.entershikari.com/enter-shikari-hospital-records-presents/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151113025114/http://www.entershikari.com/enter-shikari-hospital-records-presents/ |archive-date=13 November 2015 |access-date=6 November 2015 |publisher=Entershikari.com}}</ref> Another new single called "Hoodwinker" premiered on Daniel P. Carter's show on BBC Radio 1 on 9 October 2016.<ref>{{Cite web |date=9 October 2016 |title=Enter Shikari – #HOODWINKER |url=https://www.facebook.com/entershikari/photos/a.10150300813187104.335286.8484647103/10154042801072104/?type=3  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/8484647103/10154042801072104 |archive-date=26 February 2022 |url-access=limited|access-date=22 November 2016 |via=Facebook}}{{cbignore}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=June 2020}}

On 25 August 2016, the band announced a live album for their February 2016 Alexandra Palace show.<ref>{{Cite news |title=LIVE AT ALEXANDRA PALACE. 2xLP 2xCD DIGITAL. NOV 18th 2016  |url=http://www.entershikari.com/live-at-alexandra-palace-2xlp-2xcd-digital-nov-18th-2016/ |url-status=dead |access-date=23 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161123201453/http://www.entershikari.com/live-at-alexandra-palace-2xlp-2xcd-digital-nov-18th-2016/ |archive-date=23 November 2016}}</ref> It was initially due for release on 4 November 2016, however it was delayed until 18 November 2016 due to manufacturing issues.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Alexandra Palace album. slight delay.  |url=http://www.entershikari.com/alexandra-palace-album-slight-delay/ |url-status=dead |access-date=23 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161120100126/http://www.entershikari.com/alexandra-palace-album-slight-delay/ |archive-date=20 November 2016}}</ref>

===''The Spark'' (2017–2019)===
{{main|The Spark (album)}}

On 1 August 2017, Enter Shikari announced their new album ''[[The Spark (album)|The Spark]]'' with its lead single "Live Outside". The album was released on 22 September.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Munro |first=Scott |date=1 August 2017 |title=Enter Shikari announce new album The Spark |url=http://teamrock.com/news/2017-08-01/enter-shikari-announce-new-album-the-spark |access-date=1 August 2017 |website=TeamRock |publisher=Future Publishing Limited}}</ref>

To promote the album, the band toured UK, Europe, Japan, and North America on their ''[[The Spark World Tour]]''.

On 15 February 2019, the band released a pair of limited edition live albums, ''Take to the Skies. Live in Moscow. May 2017'' and ''Live at Alexandra Palace 2'' both of which were recorded in 2017 on their ''[[Take to the Skies]] 10 Year Anniversary Tour'' and their ''[[The Spark World Tour]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |date=29 November 2018 |title=Enter Shikari To Release Two Live Albums – Kerrang! |url=https://www.kerrang.com/the-news/enter-shikari-to-release-two-live-albums |access-date=20 August 2019 |website=[[Kerrang!]]}}</ref>

In 2018 the band embarked on an extensive tour of the UK, Europe, and Scandinavia, entitled "Stop the Clocks", during which they performed a new song of the same name.<ref>{{Cite web |date=11 July 2018 |title=Enter Shikari announce huge UK tour – Ticketmaster UK Blog |url=https://blog.ticketmaster.co.uk/music/enter-shikari-39212/ |website=Ticketmaster UK}}</ref> The band released the song as a single on 12 August 2019 shortly before their performances at the 2019 [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]] where they played 5 different sets across the weekend.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Pettigrew |first=Jason |date=12 August 2019 |title=Enter Shikari want us to 'Stop The Clocks' with new single |url=https://www.altpress.com/news/enter-shikari-stop-the-clocks-song/ |access-date=20 August 2019 |website=Alternative Press (magazine)}}</ref> Following this, the band resumed their Stop the Clocks tour with a twelve-date American leg, which singer Rou Reynolds said would "bring the whole 'Spark-era' full circle."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Shoemaker |first=Whitney |date=20 June 2019 |title=Enter Shikari announce intimate Stop The Clocks U.S. tour |url=https://www.altpress.com/news/enter-shikari-stop-the-clocks-north-america-tour/ |website=Alternative Press}}</ref>

=== ''Nothing Is True and Everything Is Possible'' (2020–present) ===
{{main|Nothing Is True & Everything Is Possible}}
In an interview with ''Kerrang'' while the band was in Australia for Good Things Festival, they revealed their next album will be the ''"most definitive Shikari record to date"'' and will feature something from every album.<ref>{{Cite web |date=10 December 2019 |title=Enter Shikari – Good Things Festival 2019 Interview |url=https://www.kerrang.com/the-news/rou-reynolds-gives-update-on-the-new-enter-shikari-album/ |access-date=11 December 2019 |website=Wall of Sound }}</ref>

On 10 February 2020, a new single called "The Dreamer's Hotel", stylised as { The Dreamer's Hotel }, premiered on Annie Mac's show on [[BBC Radio 1]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=9 February 2020 |title=#TheDreamersHotel @AnnieMac @BBCR1pic.twitter.com/LoO9CQktes |url=https://twitter.com/ENTERSHIKARI/status/1226611818279395329 |access-date=10 February 2020 |website=@ENTERSHIKARI}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}{{Primary source inline|date=June 2020}} The same day, they announced that their new album would be called ''[[Nothing Is True & Everything Is Possible]]'' and would release on 17 April 2020.<ref>{{Cite web |date=10 February 2020 |title=HERE'S EVERYTHING YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT ENTER SHIKARI'S NEW ALBUM |url=https://www.rocksound.tv/news/read/heres-everything-you-need-to-know-about-enter-shikaris-new-album |access-date=10 February 2020 |website=Rock Sound}}</ref> An accompanying music video was released for The Dreamer's Hotel on 5 March 2020, almost a month after the initial release.  The video features an unusual use of over-the-top rainbow effects, fitting with the rainbow motif of the album.<ref>{{Cite web |date=5 March 2020 |title=Official music video for The Dreamer's Hotel |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hJOiQo2ulyw  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/hJOiQo2ulyw |archive-date=21 December 2021 |url-status=live|access-date=10 March 2020 |via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> "The King" was the album's second single, released on 8 March 2020. Frontman Rou described this track as a "lesson in patience and forgiveness" to Kerrang as they have worked on this single song for such a long time.<ref>{{Cite web |date=8 March 2020 |title=Kerrang interview with Rou |url=https://www.kerrang.com/the-news/listen-to-enter-shikaris-new-song-the-king/ |access-date=10 March 2020 |website=Kerrang}}</ref> "T.I.N.A." was the third single released on 22 March 2020. The title stands for "[[there is no alternative]]". ''Nothing Is True & Everything Is Possible'' hit No. 2 on the UK album charts on 30 April 2020,{{citation needed|date=July 2020}} 13 days after its release on 17 April. This was the band's fifth album to reach Top 10 and the third consecutive major album.

On 16 April 2021, they released ''[[Moratorium (Broadcasts from the Interruption)]]'' without advance notice. It includes songs from their past two albums that have been reworked, re-imagined, recorded live or as acoustic renditions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.deadpress.co.uk/news-enter-shikari-surprise-release-new-album-moratorium/|title=NEWS: Enter Shikari surprise release new album, 'Moratorium'!|date=16 April 2021|accessdate=16 April 2021}}</ref>

On 24 November 2021 through 10 February 2022, Enter Shikari headed out for a brief European tour with a sold out headline show at Alexandra Palace.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Solomon |first=Rosie |date=17 December 2021 |title=LIVE REVIEW: Enter Shikari @ Alexandra Palace, London |url=https://distortedsoundmag.com/live-review-enter-shikari-alexandra-palace-london/ |access-date=6 March 2022 |website=Distorted Sound Magazine |language=en-GB}}</ref> On 16 July 2022, the band released their film, ''Live at Vada'', directed by Tom Pullen.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Enter Shikari - Live at VADA - A Broadcast From The Interruption |url=https://www.entershikari.com/posts/live-at-vada-a-broadcast-from-the-interruption |access-date=2022-08-17 |website=Enter Shikari}}</ref>

Enter Shikari's lyrics, written by frontman Rou Reynolds, are often politically charged. In a 2015 interview, ''[[Kerrang! Magazine]]'' wrote: "With Shikari a rare, political voice on the UK rock scene, Rou remains baffled by bands 'labelling themselves as punk that aren't speaking about anything of importance'. 'To us it's second nature,' he says. 'It's what this music is ''for''. If you take out the social commentary, it's not punk, it's just noisy pop.'" At the same time, Reynolds "[doesn't] care if people don't read the lyrics" and only "appreciate Shikari as a noisy pop group". Although not all of the band's lyrics are political, "even when [Enter Shikari write] a [[love song]], [Reynolds wants] to make sure [they] reclaim the love song from all the shit, vapid love songs on the charts." He also stated that the band's general message is that "if we base our lives around love and unity, then that's all that matters."<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Sutherland |first=Mark |date=17 January 2015 |title=Enter Shikari – Food for Thought |magazine=[[Kerrang!]] |issue=1551 |pages=22–25 (page 24)}}</ref>

Political issues that the band have written about in their lyrics include – [[climate change]] and the misuse of natural resources, [[Donald Trump]]'s presidency of the United States, the use of [[nuclear weapon]]s and the United Kingdom's [[Trident nuclear programme]],<ref>{{Cite news |date=15 March 2016 |title=Louderthanwar Enter Shikari Interview |work=Alan Ewart |publisher=Louderthanwar |url=http://louderthanwar.com/enter-shikari-interview/}}</ref> the [[privatisation]] of the UK's [[National Health Service]], and [[capitalism]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Nicholson |first=Barry |date=12 March 2015 |title=Enter Shikari Interviewed: On Circle Pits, ''Question Time'' and the General Election |work=[[NME]] |url=https://www.nme.com/features/enter-shikari-interviewed-on-circle-pits-question-time-and-the-general-election-39}}</ref>

Enter Shikari's lyrics have also centred around more personal themes throughout their career, such as lead singer Rou Reynolds' anxiety, depression, mental illness, self-pity and the loss of a loved one or idolised celebrity figure. Their album ''[[The Spark (Enter Shikari album)|The Spark]]'' in particular delves more into personal issues within the band, with Reynolds stating in an interview with ''[[The Independent]]'', regarding lyrical themes: "What I was trying to do with this album in marrying the personal and the political is to ensure that human vulnerability is laid bare, and to not be afraid to speak about emotions." He elaborates by stating that "I don’t think I could have done it [writing more personal lyrics] before this record. So much happened over those two years [since the release of their previous album], globally and in my personal life, so before. I was kind of comfortable. I have a very finely attuned cringe muscle, I don't like writing about things that have been written about a thousand times. Some of it is maybe even a self-confidence thing, feeling as though I don't have much to offer in terms of art that helps other people. But seeing as 2015 was the year of hell for me, it wasn't just that I wanted to write a more personal record, I had to. There was no way of not doing it".<ref name="RouIndependent">{{Cite news |last=O'Connor |first=Roisin |date=27 September 2017 |title=Enter Shikari's Rou Reynolds on new album 'The Spark', anxiety, and why there's no room for apathy in 2017 |work=The Independent |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/enter-shikari-interview-rou-reynolds-the-spark-album-stream-download-labour-corbyn-anxiety-donald-a7968481.html}}</ref>

In an interview following the release of ''[[A Flash Flood of Colour]]'', guitarist Rory Clewlow stated that the band's influences are numerous, but include [[Refused]], [[the Prodigy]], [[At the Drive-In]], [[Sick of It All]], [[Rage Against the Machine]], [[the Beatles]], [[Igor Stravinsky]] and [[The Dillinger Escape Plan]], and that "most of [their] sound was originally developed through going to see local acts in and around [their] home town."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Cooper |first=Ryan |title=An Interview with Rory Clewlow of Enter Shikari |url=http://punkmusic.about.com/od/interviews/a/An-Interview-With-Rory-Clewlow-Of-Enter-Shikari.htm |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402162118/http://punkmusic.about.com/od/interviews/a/An-Interview-With-Rory-Clewlow-Of-Enter-Shikari.htm |archive-date=2 April 2015 |access-date=18 February 2015 |website=About Entertainment}}</ref>

Rou Reynolds has cited British pop music from the 20th century as being a major influence on his songwriting, particularly on their album The Spark, with [[The Beatles]], [[The Damned (band)|The Damned]], [[Joy Division]] and [[New Order (band)|New Order]] being key influences on him.<ref name=RouIndependent/>

==Ambush Reality==
Ambush Reality is an [[independent record label]] owned by Enter Shikari. Although originally it was exclusively for the release of Enter Shikari's albums and songs, on 21 July 2014<ref>{{Cite web |date=21 July 2014 |title=Facebook Announcement |url=https://www.facebook.com/entershikari/photos/a.10150300813187104.335286.8484647103/10152272726332104/?type=1&theater  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/8484647103/10152272726332104 |archive-date=26 February 2022 |url-access=limited|via=Facebook |publisher=Enter Shikair}}{{cbignore}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=June 2020}} the band announced via Facebook and Twitter they were releasing a song by Nottingham hardcore band Baby Godzilla (now known as Heck). Formed in July 2006, it is co-owned and run by the members of the band and their friends.<ref>{{Cite web |title=MySpace.com – Ambush Reality – St Albans /, UK – Rock / Hardcore / Trance – www.myspace.com/ambushreality |url=http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendID=94438211 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071103232940/http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendid=94438211 |archive-date=3 November 2007 |access-date=12 March 2011 |publisher=Profile.myspace.com}}</ref> The band has decided that, to tour in the United States, they had to sign with a [[Music market|major record label]] in America.<ref>{{Cite magazine |title=U.K.'s Enter Shikari Scores Without Label |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1053180/uks-enter-shikari-scores-without-label |magazine=Billboard |access-date=12 March 2011}}</ref> On 28 August 2007, Ambush Reality said that ''Take to the Skies'' came out in North America in October 2007, with Ambush Reality joining [[Interscope Records]] imprint [[Tiny Evil]]. Ambush Reality signed a distribution deal with [[Warner Music]] to make the album ''[[Common Dreads]]'' and future releases more accessible outside the UK and also more widely advertised and promoted.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Enter Shikari Official Forum • View topic – USA Label Update? |url=http://www.entershikari.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=284 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227045700/http://www.entershikari.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=284 |archive-date=27 February 2009 }}</ref> As of 8 December 2010 Enter Shikari / Ambush Reality have left distribution through Warner and will distribute throughout UK/Europe/Japan/Australia via [[PIAS Entertainment Group]].
As of 21 June 2011, Enter Shikari's releases in North America are via [[independent record label]] [[Hopeless Records]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Enter Shikari Sign With Hopeless Records |url=http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/enter_shikari_sign_with_hopeless_records |access-date=9 April 2012 |website=Alternative Press|date=21 June 2011 }}</ref>

== Side projects ==
Reynolds has produced music as part of a side project with the name "Rout",<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rout |url=http://www.facebook.com/routdj |access-date=22 November 2016 |via=Facebook}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}{{Primary source inline|date=June 2020}} which he sometimes performs in small venues and before shows. He previously used the names "Shark & Blitz" and "Routron 5000".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.myspace.com/routron5000 |access-date=12 March 2011 |publisher=Myspace.com|title=Routron 5000 (S&B UP NOW!) | Listen and Stream Free Music, Albums, New Releases, Photos, Videos }}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}{{Primary source inline|date=June 2020}} The music develops on his penchant for electronics, resulting in a drum and bass/jungle/dubstep sound. Some songs feature samples of Rou and friends fooling around as well as iconic lines from movies or songs.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rout on Music Glue |url=http://www.routmusic.com/ |access-date=22 November 2016 |publisher=Routmusic.com}}</ref>
His most recent EP, released for [[ActionAid]], features samples from [[ActionAid]]'s project work in [[Ghana]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.actionaid.org.uk/101322/blog.html?article=4504 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130201040741/http://www.actionaid.org.uk/101322/blog.html?article=4504 |archive-date=1 February 2013 |access-date=11 October 2012 |publisher=ActionAid|title=Bollocks to poverty - ActionAid UK's youth network :: ActionAid UK }}</ref>

Rolfe also DJs under the moniker "Sgt. Rolfy", regularly playing slots at the band's aftershow parties. He plays a range of sounds, including trance, drum & bass, dubstep and even classical and parody tunes too.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Sgt. Rolfy | Free Listening on SoundCloud |url=http://soundcloud.com/sgt-rolfy |access-date=22 November 2016 |publisher=Soundcloud.com}}</ref>

Clewlow recently released his first remix, simply as "Rory C", for [[Don Broco]]'s track "Priorities", from their new record.<ref>{{Cite web |title=RORY C |url=http://soundcloud.com/roryctunes |website=SoundCloud}}</ref>

Reynolds has also set up his own clothing company, Step Up Clothing.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Step Up Hq |url=http://www.stepuphq.com |website=stepuphq.com}}</ref>

On 25 April 2013 the band announced a side project called Shikari Sound System, an alter-ego of the group. The band announced it on their Facebook page straight after they had been announced to play at Reading and Leeds Festival during the summer.<ref>{{Cite web |date=25 April 2013 |title=Shikari Sound System @ Reading + Leeds 2013 |url=http://www.entershikari.com/shikari-sound-system-reading-leeds-2013/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401015105/http://www.entershikari.com/shikari-sound-system-reading-leeds-2013/ |archive-date=1 April 2016 |access-date=18 January 2016 |website=Entershikari.com}}</ref> Frontman Rou assured fans on his Twitter page that it would be "The same 4 scallywags but playing a live dance set".<ref name="sss-tweet">{{Cite web |last=Davies |first=Alan |date=18 May 2013 |title=Reading and Leeds Festival world exclusive from Enter Shikari band members |url=http://www.whtimes.co.uk/what-s-on/music/reading_and_leeds_festival_world_exclusive_from_enter_shikari_band_members_1_2200484 |access-date=18 January 2016 |website=Welwyn Hatfield Times}}</ref> Shikari Sound System played their debut set at The Reading and Leeds festivals and were joined by members of hardcore band [[Hacktivist (band)|Hacktivist]] as well as Danny Price who now regularly hosts SSS DJ sets. Shikari Sound System were announced for [[Slam Dunk Festival]] on 24 February 2016<ref>{{Cite web |last=Davies |first=Alan |title=Slam Dunk Festival 2016 line-up additions include Shikari Sound System and The King Blues |url=http://www.whtimes.co.uk/what-s-on/music/slam_dunk_festival_2016_line_up_additions_include_shikari_sound_system_and_the_king_blues_1_4431242 |access-date=20 March 2016 |website=Welwyn Hatfield Times|date=24 February 2016 }}</ref> and have done regular slots in the UK and Europe.

In 2017, Rou Reynolds released a book named ''Dear Future Historians'', a song-by-song lyrical analysis of the band's work including photos. By popular demand, the book was revisited and expanded in 2019 to include music released since its original publication, and received another strictly limited edition run.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Enter Shikari – Dear Future Historians: 2006–2019 Expanded Paperback Release |url=https://www.entershikari.com/posts/dear-future-historians-2006-2019 |website=Enter Shikari}}</ref>

In August 2020, it was announced that Enter Shikari would become the main sponsor of their hometown team, [[St Albans City F.C.|St Albans City Football Club]].<ref>{{Cite news |date=2020-08-14 |title=St Albans City sponsored by rock band Enter Shikari |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-53785493 |access-date=2022-05-12}}</ref> In 2022, Chris Batten signed on with the football club to play one football match against [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.]] to raise money to support those affected by the [[Russian invasion of Ukraine|Russian Invasion of Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Charlesworth |first=Ricky |date=2022-03-28 |title=Rock star signs with non-league club and set to make debut aged 35 |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/enter-shikari-st-albans-batten-26576537 |access-date=2022-05-12 |website=mirror |language=en}}</ref>

== Members ==
* Rou Reynolds – lead vocals, [[programming (music)|programming]], synthesizer, keyboards, acoustic guitar, rhythm guitar, trumpet, percussion <small>(1999–present)</small>
* Chris Batten – bass, vocals, synthesizer, keyboards, percussion <small>(1999–present)</small>
* Rob Rolfe – drums, percussion, backing vocals <small>(1999–present)</small>
* Rory Clewlow – lead guitar, vocals, percussion, keyboards, synthesizer <small>(2003–present)</small>
